awd_titl_txt: CAREER: SUNCROPS (Solar-Fuels Using Nanoscale Catalysts Reacting on Polymer-modified Surfaces)
awd_abstract_narration:
Catalysts are chemical substances that provide an alternative pathway for chemical reactions to occur that is less energy-intensive and  more rapid than the pathway taken without the catalyst present. Some catalysts are difficult to recover when the catalytic process is completed.  Attaching them to a solid surface improves their recoverability and gives an additional route to tailor their catalytic ability. Dr. Gary F. Moore and his team of researchers at Arizona State University are developing innovative ways to create and assemble polymeric surface coatings that attach molecular catalysts to solids that are useful for solar energy capture and storage. The catalyst-polymer construct stabilizes the component materials and enhances their utility for generating fuels and other value-added chemical products with minimal environmental impact, giving broader societal impacts to his research. Dr. Moore is active in outreach programs that engage students in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines using topics that draw on advancements made in his research in chemical catalysis and energy science. These activities include research opportunities in Dr. Moore's laboratory to promote the education of under-served students from local high schools and Native American tribes. His integration of research, education, and societal impact broadens student participation in science, and is a major component of this CAREER grant.

With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Gary F. Moore is pioneering novel synthetic methodologies to immobilize molecular redox catalysts onto semi-conducting and conducting solids while retaining or enhancing their activity using surface-grafted polymers as a soft scaffold.  In these extended polymer matrices, key features of biological enzymes are incorporated into the catalyst design and include extended ligation spheres, channels for substrate delivery and product removal, and regeneration strategies for spent catalysts. The functionality of these materials is under investigation for (photo)electrochemically activation of a range of industrially relevant redox couples, including the H+/H2, CO2/CO and N2/NH3 transformations, and the catalyst activity is examined using (photo)electrochemical characterization techniques. Surface-sensitive characterization methods including grazing angle Fourier transform infrared and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopies. Broader societal impact of the research results from improved catalyst designs for solar generation of fuels and other value-added chemical products.  Dr. Moore is actively engaged in STEM outreach programs that provide mentorship and research opportunities to traditionally under-served students from local high schools and Native American tribes, encouraging promising students early in their academic endeavors and inspiring their pursuit of STEM careers. His integration of research, education, and societal impact broadens student participation in science, and is a major component of this CAREER grant.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
A driving hypothesis of this research project is that polymeric coatings can provide an interface for coupling the promising features of molecular components, including catalysts, with those of bulk solid-state materials via cooperative interactions. Inspired by the role of protein environments in biological assemblies, our research group has developed synthetic methods to chemically graft thin-film polymeric coatings onto solid-state conducting or semiconducting surfaces. The polymers used in assembling these hybrid heterogeneous-homogeneous architectures provide a mechanism to direct, template, and assemble molecular components for activating fuel-forming reactions at appropriate functional groups along surface-grafted polymer chains. Further, the three-dimensional soft-material matrix of the polymer coatings provides confined environments with redundant ligand sites, which chemically stabilize embedded catalysts during redox cycling and afford a protective coating for the underlying (semi)conducting surfaces. Thus, the polymeric coatings provide a molecular-based strategy for enhancing the stability and activity of the immobilized catalysts, as well as the underpinning solid-state supports. Conversely the solid-state (semi)conducting supports provide a means for electrochemically or photoelectrochemically activating the immobilized fuel-forming catalysts.

The polymer grafting procedure used in this work leveraged a photo-induced immobilization chemistry of alkenes to surfaces and provided a means for attaching catalytic complexes to surface-bound functional groups of the polymer. The modularity of this method enabled independent modification of the surface, polymeric interface, or catalysts, and permitted fabrication of electrodes for subsequent (photo)electrochemical characterization. Outcomes of these investigations demonstrated (i) the polymer grafting method can be performed on semiconducting and conducting substrates, (ii) the catalyst-polymer grafting is not limited to a specific crystal face orientation, (iii) the polymer functional groups can be customized to control the chemical activity of the overall assembly, (iv) molecular-scale changes to the ligand environment of surface-immobilized complexes affect the photoelectrochemical response observed at the construct level, (v) the polymer immobilization strategy is not limited to a single class of molecular catalysts, and (vi) the polymeric layer enables reassembly of catalysts that detach during fuel-forming operation.

One strength of the molecular-based and bioinspired strategies used in our research program is the diversity in structure and function these approaches enable. The notion that diversity brings increased creativity and promotes innovation is leveraged not only in the constructed materials, but also in the educational and outreach aspects of this project. The research work described here served as a vehicle for broadening participation in research. In addition to working in a laboratory setting, students participated in research programs designed to support the current theory of situated learning. Situated learning recognizes that proper learning cannot take place in a classroom where information is transferred in an abstract way; instead it requires activity within the culture in which it occurs. This method of learning also better engages students and helps to enculture them into a community of practice. Laboratory research was specifically designed for high school and undergraduate researchers focused on establishing skills in synthesizing and characterizing chemical catalysts. High school students presented their work to their peers at the end of their projects, and undergraduate researchers incorporated their laboratory experiences into their degree program through research credits that complemented their coursework. In summary, the outcomes of this project have contributed to the advancement of knowledge through new discoveries and through training a new, diverse generation of scientists that will advance future understandings and innovations in chemistry.

 


Last Modified: 05/01/2023
Modified by: Gary F Moore
